comments.content:
Chances are it's hand lettered using a template, most technical drawings are hand lettered / template lettered.

I'd suggest [Simpliciter Sans](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415225710/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/larstornqvist/simpliciter-sans/)

DIN16 should do as well.

Edit: [FF DIN](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415225710/http:/www.fontshop.com/?fuseaction=catalog.fontpackage&searchby=manufacturer&displayfontid=FF.9467.0.0) comes close actually...

Good call, Asvetic. Another rounded, template-based option would be Gravur Condensed from Lineto.

[http://lineto.com/The+Fonts/Font+Categories/Text+Fonts/Gravur+Condensed/](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415225710/http:/lineto.com/The+Fonts/Font+Categories/Text+Fonts/Gravur+Condensed/ "http://lineto.com/The+Fonts/Font+Categories/Text+Fonts/Gravur+Condensed/")

or [Bryant](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415225710/http:/www.processtypefoundry.com/typefaces/bryant2/info.html)

_...modeled around the popular Wrico lettering kits used by draftsmen and amateur sign makers in the 1960s and ’70s..._
Or [DIN 17](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415225710/http:/www.fontshop.com/showfont.cfm?fid=SG.9416.0.0). I do not know 16, Vincent. Can you show?

[Chevin](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415225710/http:/www.veer.com/products/typedetail.aspx?image=GTT0000003) - like a more characterful, rounded Din.

Nick Cooke

Stephen, I couldn't find a link on FontShop nor MyFonts. I did find it under [FontFactory](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415225710/http:/www.fontfactory.com/). There is also [an old thread on Typophile](http://web.archive.org/web/20120415225710/http:/typophile.com/node/2251). Can't seem to find a purchase link I'm afraid...

Ahh, funny that I recommended 16 in that thread. 2003 -- so long ago.

Mecanorma is sadly in trademark limbo. Cannot purchase ahora.

Think I got it from a friend back in 2000–2001. Wanted to get my hands on any fonts that were clean & geometric after having used several letter rulers in Secondary school. Just loved setting them on paper with a traditional pen!
